Investment.Caption: by Retirement
Investment.Commentary: The average annual yield of your retirement portfolio may be more or less than our estimates. Use the controls above to adjust the yield to match what your investment advisor has projected, as well as the number of years remaining before you expect to retire.

Investment.Caption: after [Years] years in Index Funds
Investment.Commentary: The Compound Annual Growth Rate of the Standard & Poor 500 Index since its inception in 1957 is about 9.62%, however this is not what you'll typically expect in any given year; in some years the index does worse than others, some years it does much better. When investing in such a fund you should be thinking about the long term and be willing to ride-out dips in the market that can make it look as if you're losing money.

Investment.Caption: after [Years] years in a savings account
Investment.Commentary:
Savings accounts are traditionally low-interest earners, but in the last 7 years many banks have introduced high-interest savings accoungs that can earn up to 5 times more than the national average. Our estimates come from the interest rate offered by a popular high-interest savings account, as of July 2012.
Change the Savings APR above to reflect what your bank is reporting for your savings account to see more accurate estimates.

Investment.Caption: under the mattress for [Years] years

Configurable.Name: Years
Configurable.Label: I plan to raid this after

Investment.Commentary:
The phrase "stuffing money under the mattress" might have come from the Depression era, when banks were failing and the FDIC (Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation) didn't exist yet.
According to the Federal Reserve about one in every 12 families, or 8.7 percent of the US population, do not have a bank account. The majority of those are immigrants with low incomes who may be inhibited by a language barrier, or because they distrust traditional financial institutions.
Another reason for going without a bank account, especially for low-income workers, are the fees: monthly service fees and overdraft fees are more common when you can't keep much money in your account at any time. Plus, the number of banks offering free checking accounts has dwindled rapidly since 2008.

TimeOfService.Caption: of labor to earn
TimeOfService.Commentary:
Modify the above to match your hourly wage so you can quickly see how long you need to work to earn any given amount.
As a comparison, the US Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that the average hourly salary of an employee in the United States was $23.38 as of April 2012, which is where we picked our initial estimate from.

LoanPayoff.Caption: to pay-off credit card in [Periods] months
LoanPayoff.Commentary:
The total payoff includes the principal plus the interest. This calculator assumes that you'll only make minimum payments, defined as the interest plus a percentage of the balance. Try increasing the Percent-After-Interest to see how much you'd save if you paid more each month.
Making only minimum payments can force you to pay an enormous amount of interest over time thanks to monthly compounding and low monthly payments: even if the interest rate is only 14% per year, putting $100 on a credit card does not mean you'll only ever to pay $14 in interest, in fact you may pay much more.
The first trick they use, monthly compounding means that they calculate your interest and add it to your balance each month. That means that by the second month they're now charging you interest on the interest. Before the CARD act of 2009, some banks even charged more interest than the minimum payment could cover, creating an escalating debt problem called Negative Amortization that you can never escape from.
The second trick is to make the minimum monthly payment as low as possible in order to stretch out the time it takes you to pay-off the card, sometimes to many years or decades. The longer you carry a balance the more often they can use monthly compounding to charge you more interest.
So what's the best way to use credit cards? Many smart shoppers pay-off their credit card balance in full each month, while it's still in the grace period. The grace period is when you can pay-off the balance of the card without being charged interest, and lasts for about 20 days after you use the card.
Even if you can't pay the balance in full, every time you pay more than the minimum balance the extra amount will chip away at the principal balance, meaning that it bites-off more of the balance that they're using to calculate your interest the following month.

SpendingPower.Caption: for a new car in [Installments] monthly payments
SpendingPower.Commentary:
The actual amount of money you can borrow will depend on your income, cash flow and credit history. What you see here is an estimate based on the assumption that you will qualify for such a loan, and is only meant to help you get an idea of what you could finance.
Only your bank or financing company can tell you how much you can actually borrow and what kind of interest rate you qualify for. Most new-car loans tend to come with a lower rate than used-car loans because a new car will be covered by a manufacturer's warrantee, which lowers the risk to the lender. Your credit history will also affect the interest rate and maximum loan amount, as lenders are less willing to loan large amounts at low rates to those who may have defaulted on a loan in the past, or haven't yet established a good payment history.

SpendingPower.Caption: for a used car in [Installments] monthly payments
SpendingPower.Commentary:
They say that a new car loses half of its value the moment you drive it off the dealer's lot, but at the same time the loans for buying used cars tend to have a slightly higher interest rate over a shorter period of time (60 months for new cars, 36 months for used).
Used cars also tend to incur more repair costs and have a shorter lifetime, so while they may be cheaper to buy initially, you need to be careful to balance price versus economy. If you plan to drive the same car for more than 6 years, you may wish to consider a new car instead because most of your maintenance expenses will be covered by the warrantee.
Indeed, some studies have suggested that the most economical choice is to buy a new car and drive it until it falls apart.

SpendingPower.Caption: mortgage, with [Installments] monthly payments
SpendingPower.Commentary:
The above estimate doesn't include any closing costs or down payments that you may also incur when buying a house, but it may help you determine roughly how much you can finance for a given monthly payment.
Change the APR above to match what your mortgage lender has quoted you to see more accurate estimates.

UnitsPerPeriod.Caption: large cappuccinos per day
UnitsPerPeriod.Commentary: Based on the average price of a Grande Cappucino from a national coffee restaurant chain.

UnitsPerPeriod.Caption: movie rentals per week
UnitsPerPeriod.Commentary:
Based on the price of a High-Defenition New Release rental on Apple's iTunes movie store.
Not all movies cost this much to rent, as older releases, Standard Definition rentals, and weekly specials can bring the price of a 24-hour rental to as low as 99 cents.

UnitsPerPeriod.Caption: movie tickets per week
UnitsPerPeriod.Commentary:
Our estimate comes from the average nationwide ticket price in 2012, but those prices have been steadily increasing since movies first began to be shown. In an effort to make more profit at the box office, studios and cinemas have been adding features such as 3D effects, digital projection, and even doubling the frame rate from 24-Frames Per Second (FPS) to 48, all to justify higher and higher ticket prices.
In the meantime, digital movie rentals, convenience-store DVD rental kiosks and mail-driven services such as Netflix have made it cheaper and easier than ever to watch movies at home.

UnitsPerPeriod.Caption: fast-food meals per week
UnitsPerPeriod.Commentary: Fast food is certainly convenient, but the costs can add up quickly and they rarely save more than about 10 or 11 minutes over preparing your meals yourself. Once you add the long-term health benefits of cooking at home, reducing your fast-food consumption by just 1 meal a week can be worth $528 per year plus a much longer, healthier life to spend it in.

UnitsPerPeriod.Caption: subway rides per week
UnitsPerPeriod.Commentary:
Once you add the cost of fuel, insurance, and maintenance to your loan payments, an automobile can easily cost over $600 per month to own. But if you live in a city with subway or bus service, it may cost as little as $90 per month to commute to-and-from work every day.
Most cities also offer ways to save even more money by purchasing pre-paid fare cards or even weekly and monthly unlimited ride cards that work out even cheaper per ride.

UnitsPerPeriod.Caption: console games per year
UnitsPerPeriod.Commentary:
Video games, although sometimes expensive, actually offer a very economical form of entertainment. With some studies indicating that gamers spend an average of 13 hours a week playing their favorites, a game that you play for 2 or 3 weeks can work out to only pennies per hour of enjoyment. Far cheaper than renting movies.
Beware, of course, the endless stream of accessories and upgrades, subscription fees for online gaming, and the sudden evaporation of your social life.

UnitsPerPeriod.Caption: CFL bulbs per year

Configurable.Name: Cost
Configurable.Label: Average cost of a CFL bulb

UnitsPerPeriod.Commentary:
Compact Flourescent Light Bulbs (CFLs) use less energy (as much as 75% less) and can last for 9 years longer than an incandescent light bulb of the same brightness. According to the Hinkle Charitable Foundation, a typical apartment with 20 bulbs can save $1,4000 in electricity over the lifetime of those bulbs by converting to CFL.
Our estimate for the cost of a CFL bulb is the average for a 60W equivalent bulb purchased at a typical home improvement store.

TimeOfService.Caption: of daily newspaper delivery
TimeOfService.Commentary:
In the age of the Internet, daily door-stop newspaper delivery seems antiquated, and almost all newspapers around the world have seen their subscriber base steadily shrink as people get their news from cheaper, more quickly-updated sources online.
Some newspapers are trying to fight back. The New York Times, where we obtained our price estimate from, is including access to premium content on its web site and iPad app as part of a basic Home Delivery subscription.
So now you can get your news in the most convenient form while still having the prestige of an old-fashioned newspaper sitting on your breakfast table each day.

UnitsForPrice.Caption: ambulance rides
UnitsForPrice.Commentary:
Ambulance transport varies widely in the United States, with most billings coming between $500 and $1,000, but you may be lucky enough to live in an area where ambulance service is provided free by the city or county.
The most expensive emergency ride you can get, however, is an Airlift, or hellicopter ambulance, which can add more than $2,000 to your hospital bill. An airlift is called for by paramedics for certain types of injury, especially head injuries that could have caused damage to the brain.

TimeUntil.Commentary:
Based on the average price of the top-20 highest customer rated dishwashers on Amazon.com.
Modify the Average price above to match what you've budgeted for and help you figure out what it'll take to reach your goal.

TimeUntil.Caption: to save for a home treadmill
TimeUntil.Commentary: Based on the average price of the top-20 highest customer rated motorized treadmills on Amazon.com.

TimeUntil.Commentary: Based on the average price of the top-20 highest customer rated espresso machines on Amazon.com

TimeUntil.Caption: to save for a vacation for 2 in Hawaii
TimeUntil.Commentary: Based on $550 per-person for air-travel, $1,225 for 7 hotel nights at $175 per night, $455 for food, $540 for activities and $450 to rent a car for the week.

TimeUntil.Caption: to save for a Home Theater system
TimeUntil.Commentary:
Our $5,000 estimate would cover a 42-inch flat-screen TV, a surround-sound system with five speakers, Blu-Ray DVD player and a basic infrared remote. We didn't include some of the more expensive options such as professional installation, sound-proofing your room and installing theater seats, which can add another $30,000 or more to the budget.
If that high-end experience is what you're looking for then just tap on the Average price above and enter what your contractor has quoted you.

UnitsPerPeriod.Caption: doses of Polio vaccine per day
UnitsPerPeriod.Commentary:
It costs surprisingly little to vaccinate a child against polio. The good news is that it appears to be working, as India was declared entirely polio-free in 2012 by the World Health Organization.
Source: Global Polio Eradication Initiative.

UnitsForPrice.Caption: Nimitz-class Aircraft Carriers
UnitsForPrice.Commentary: The largest capital ships in the world are Nimitz-class supercarriers, typically displacing over 90,000 tons and deployed with at least three other ships as part of a carrier strike group. As of 2012 the United States Navy has 11 carrier strike groups in active service.

TimeUntil.Caption: to pay for a Moon Base
TimeUntil.Commentary:
As a current or future President of the United States, you may be looking for ways to make your mark in the history books, and what better way than to establish a permanent, manned research base on The Moon?
An analysis performed in 2009 by the Center for Strategic and International Studies (a policy Think-Tank) estimates that such a lunar base would cost about $35 billion and require an additional $7.35 billion per year in operational costs.
